segments.text: All right.
Well, now, what further questions?

Well, I think, actually, all that we have you to, really, is 1953, when you're going to leave the Bureau, when you, well, really until 51, when you begin, evidently, to think about leaving the Bureau of Mines in 51 or 52.
And you leave in 53.
Is there any particular reason why you decided to leave the government and join academe?
Yes, I think there were specific reasons.
One, I felt that it was going to be many years before we were going to go into a synthetic fuel program because of the vast reserves of the Middle East.
And I felt under those circumstances that...
less interested in synthetic fields.
And so to that extent, I had thought that this thing was so far off in the future that I'd do better to devote a considerable amount of my energy to other studies.
And so I came out here to the University of Maryland.
I did continue a modest amount of work with the Spencer Chemical Company and the El Paso Natural Gas Company.
But I also did a good deal of consulting work in connection with building ammonia plants and urea plants and things of that nature.
And I didn't really resume my interest in synthetic fuels until the late 1960s.
And I think officially that's the way it might be expressed.
I have another question for you.
It's sort of a loaded question.

Do you suppose if you had a chance to go back through the government documents again, through the German documents and the government documents again, would they call things back to your attention you think that you had missed before?
Well, during the past few years, since my interest in synthetic fuels has revived, I have done a lot of that.
I have reviewed a lot of that.

And in connection with this work for the National Academy of Engineering, we have, in fact, reviewed every process that is publicly described for either the fissure structure or the cool hydrogenation process.
That includes things like the Winklers and the Schmalfeld and the...
Yes, yes it does.
I see.
And those reports from the National Academy of Engineers, as I say, there have been five committees working on them, and there's about six or eight men on each committee.
And those reports ought to be out this year.
I'll look for those.
OK. Oh, stop the record a minute.
Now, that's the reason why I'm interested in how, when you go back through these documents in archives,
And we look at them.
Let me begin a question with a question, which is a dumb way to do things.
But if one is an historian and he goes over the same sources from five different angles, usually other things occur to him as he goes through.
That is, he looks for different things.
For example, when he's reading a letter and writing a book, things that you missed the first time occur to you the second time.
Is the same thing true in your work?
Yes, it is.
Every time I go over this, I see certain things from a different angle.
And...
see things that I didn't see before, and I'm sure that if I went over data again, I would still see other angles.
But as a matter of fact, my interest in this is continuing, and I am doing that to the extent that I can, even at the present time.
Okay.
Now, so when you look at a document, you say, well, since I'm using Germans and synthetic fuels as an example, I'm going to stay with them.
You're saying, now, if they had dropped this and done this, for example, then this might possibly work?
That's the way you arrive at things?
Yeah.
All right.
And do you also say, then, if they had done this and this, if we add this in terms of modern technology, would that be the solution?
Yes, and... Now, what I want to know is...
I think that ERDA has...
is paying people like the Floor Corporation and other people to try and do that right now.
And they are making extensive cost studies of various combinations of processes and everything like this to try to arrive at more economical solutions.
Now, if I understand it presently, that there are at least two approaches to the use of synthetic oils, one trying to build
should I say, or add to the information from World War I in terms of continuous use of technology and the other trying to turn the direction of the technology.
Okay, that's... And I also should mention to you that the University of Utah is doing some very interesting work that...
By the way, I think it's referred to in that paper, so you can get a copy of their work.
The man out there to talk to if you want to talk to him about the University of New York is Wendell Weiser.
He's the man who runs the work out there.
Was he involved in?
He's been involved in this committee work at the National Academy of Engineers.
He would be a very good man to talk to.
Okay.
When did this National Academy of Engineers work begin?
When did their work begin in synthetic fuels?
Well, now I've got to answer that in two ways.
We started gasification work at the National Academy of Engineering and studied high BTU gasification about six or eight years ago.
And this last program started about two years ago, dealing particularly with synthetic fuels, which is your prime interest in this interview, I think.
Has there been much connection between the National Academy and, for instance, the high gas process development at the Illinois Institute of Technology?
Yes, we've had very close contact with those people.
As a matter of fact, Henry Liven, who's the president of high gas, is on one of the committees of the National Academy of Engineering.
And Frank Skora, who is the vice president of IGT, is a very good personal friend of mine, and I've talked to him quite often.
And we have one man by the name of Bill Bodle who is on the liquefaction committee that we're talking about.
So they're well involved in this.
And the oil companies have people on these committees.
The universities have people on these committees, and so on and so forth.
You better get a good story about these committees from Bob Crozier.
Yes.
Because I think you ought to give a little story.
No question about it.
No question about it.
Because it seems like the decisions... A few pages, anyway.
Oh, to be sure.
Because it seems like the culmination of this is in the National Academy.
And you know there's been all kinds of cost studies made on this by ECAS and by Florida Corporation and by...
Parsons and by practically every big construction company in the country paid for by IRDA, or partly paid for by IRDA.
And the oil companies themselves have made cost studies and so on and so forth.
So it's a very, very broad attack on the problem.
I take it that you came straight into the chemistry department here at Maryland in 53, 54.
Chemical engineering.
Chemical engineering department, excuse me.
Chemical engineering department.
Yes, yes.
And then remained here from 53?
Yes.
The work I did from 53 to 60 on coal hydrogenation was on a consulting basis.
Okay.
It had nothing to do with the University of Maryland.
And did your...

What were your interests other than synthetic fuels between 53 and, I know it's hard to ask me what his interests were over the last 20 years, but I mean in terms of professional... Well, largely I got involved in, aside from the small amount of work I did in synthetic, in coal hydrogenation at that time, my work was largely in connection with
ammonia and urea plants, and I served as a consulting chemical engineer for the Indonesian government for seven years out of that time.
We built two plants for producing ammonia and urea, one in Sumatra and one in Java, and that took most of my time.
I did quite a lot of work for the Atomic Energy Commission.
I work for Reynolds Metals Company and various corporations.
I think it's all in my, not in detail, but my... No, I can't, partially it's here in your vitae.
All right.
Orrin, do you have any questions?
Yes, I'd like to inquire, do you ever, going back to the TOM, the technical oil mission that we started, that we talked about earlier, do you ever see any of these technical oil mission people?
Are they in business or are they in industry or have they, like you, put their...
earlier experience to work, or did they go on into something else?
Do you see these people?
Do you know?
I saw them for a period of perhaps eight to ten years after we concluded that work, up until about 1960 or so.
But since then, I've seen very little of them.
But most of those people are probably, many of them I know are retired.
I still have Christmas cards from them and things like that, but they're retired and they're out of the work.
One or two of them are still active.
One or two of the Bureau of Mines people, Zeke Clark and Martin Elliott and a few people like that are still active, but there are a few of them.
And you know Henry Linden,
I mentioned the IGT person.

He once made the statement that at the time this oil problem broke on us in the late 60s, or however you want to put it, that there probably weren't more than 100 to 200 people who really knew anything about synthetic fuels who were still active.
And I guess that's probably a fair statement, really.
And that left a tremendous gap in our technological ability and made it very difficult for her to get started.
What we're trying to do is to rebuild this technology.
What astonished me about it all was that a whole technology such as the Germans had built up could be completely lost.
It was completely lost in Germany, too.
I've talked to the Germans, and some of them hardly knew that there was a German synthetic fuel technology, the younger German people.
That's a very good point.
What would you say accounted for the lack of transition between wartime and peacetime
Well, I think, again, it was this tremendous flood of oil that took all the synthetic fuel technology out of the picture.
It wouldn't be political.
I don't think it was political.
I don't think it was political.
And I don't think it had anything to do with the fact that the oil companies necessarily wanted to lose the technology.
I think it was a fact that the economics were against the technology and there was little reason to support it.
You know about the fisher tropics plants in South Africa, don't you?
Yes, the Sasso.
You know there is the Sasso plant.
It's about a 5,000 barrel a day plant, which was built in 1953.
And that was the last big synthetic fuel plant that was ever built.
And now, of course, you know that they are building another plant, much like the Sasso plant.
It's not exactly the same design, but it's similar.
And it's supposed to produce 40,000 barrels.
I think it's about 100 miles from Cecil.
It's a new location.
But the South Africans, I think, have taken the position that they want an independent oil production regardless of economic costs.
That's not a bad position to take because I think we... We may have to take the same position.
Yes, who knows?
And maybe we will.
And when they do, if such a decision is made, for instance, by the National Academy or by anybody... Or by her or the government.
I don't want the government to do less.
The more we fool with that, the better off we are, in my opinion.
Yes, right.
As a matter of fact, the Texas A&M University and the Center for Energy and Mental Resources prides itself on the fact that we have turned to private industry for our support, and we did not...
Yes, you've got all private industry.
Yes.
There were no funds there either.
Rockefeller Foundation.
Oh, no.
This is all done by...
It's not funded in any way by... Erd is interested, and Erd is...
I'm glad to know that.
Oh, we have...
This is not for...
It doesn't matter.
...people that are still around or...
you feel might have had some experiences that might... Miller's dead, isn't he?
You don't know, huh?
Yeah, he is dead.
He's an older man than that.
He is dead.
That's Albert Miller.
Albert E. Miller, yeah, he's gone.
Farragut is gone.
There was a fellow by the name of Jones at Coppers who was very active.
Kenneth Gordon is gone.
Allred is dead, I believe.
Harold Atwell was with me a lot.
I believe Harold Atwell, he's retired from the Texas company.
I know whether he's dead or not, I don't know.
Those are the ones that occurred to my mind.
Well, we know Petty John is still alive.
Petty John's still living.
He's in Sarasota.
He wasn't with our group, but he was certainly a very active one.
He led the oil mission, the Navy oil mission over there, right?
And I'm sure he can tell a few people from his own mission that may be around and so on and so on.
There's one or two people in the oil companies that I know are still active, but their names get away from me.
There was a Reiser or a Rensler or a Rissler or somebody up in Connecticut.
I remember reading about Richler, Reisler, Rensler.
What's that name?
I can't think of his name.
I think the best thing for you to do, though, is to get those names off those reels, because those papers were all authored by people who were involved in the missions.
Right.
I just thought if you were still on good terms with them locally, we could pick up the phone and say howdy.
A lot of these people I saw very little after the mission was over.
And our few meetings here in Washington, and it's only when you give me the names that I recall them.
Whereas the people I worked with in the Bureau of Mines, I mean, I had much closer association with them.
And they and their names stick in my mind.
But most of those people, too, are either retired or dead.
Would you want to hazard a guess on what you think the future of synthetic oil is to the country?
That is, do you think it's going to come or not come?
Well, I think that the United States particularly has got to find some way to convert our large reserves of coal to liquid and gaseous fuels.
And I think that synthetic fuels has to come.
But whether it's before the year 2000 or not, I don't know.
And that will depend, I think, not only on our own technical ability, which is part of the story.
I think there are technical possibilities that have still not yet been properly explored.
But it's also going to depend on what attitude the Arabs take
future cost of oil.
My own feeling is also that we're going to have to develop our nuclear energy plants.
I see no other solution to this than to develop nuclear energy.
We've got to learn to live with this nuclear energy.
We have to learn to take care of those plant residues and so on and so forth.
And we've got to get this big load from the electric power plants off of coal
and off of oil and gas as fast as we can, I believe.
That's my opinion of the situation.
Now, if you ask me about solar energy and wind energy and things like this, I think these are all future, maybe after the year 2000, but I can't see that far ahead, really.
That's all I need to know.
Do you need to know anything for your program?
No, I can't think of anything.
Anything you'd like to add?
No, I think that covers practically everything.
Do we sit here and exhaust you for three hours?
Yes.
